Issues.Title: System.Drawing.SystemIcons.Shield icon is incorrect in Windows 7 and above
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Not sure. Also unsure if it worked in .Net Framework or not.

### Issue description

According to https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.drawing.systemicons.shield, the shield icon should be used on any control whose default action requires elevation to administrator privileges. Looking at https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/uxguide/winenv-uac, the shield icon used to indicate elevation is required is a **blue and yellow shield** whereas SystemIcons.Shield, despite being recommended for controls whose default action requires elevation, uses a **red, green, blue and yellow shield** icon as you can see in the image below:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43898231/223266711-abfca92a-f9ca-4088-9fda-8f6b72567132.png).
If we look at some UIs in Windows 11, it uses a blue and yellow shield as expected:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43898231/223267373-e7ffd394-fc78-46e0-9adb-c0b40af3323f.png)

It seems that the icon used in System.Drawing.SystemIcons.Shield is actually the older icon from Windows Vista:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43898231/223275305-d07f6cde-edd4-4651-859b-ae7291f572bd.png)
Whereas it seems to have been changed in to the blue and yellow in Windows 7 and above, but the one in System.Drawing.SystemIcons.Shield was never updated:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43898231/223275455-65ffda41-c1c8-45fc-84e4-150f3e11eb45.png)


### Steps to reproduce

Show System.Drawing.SystemIcons.Shield anywhere in a UI.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.Drawing.SystemIcons.Shield icon is incorrect in Windows 7 and above" (#8753)

Issues.Title: [API Proposal]: Define a pattern for default values that used to be constants proportional to the default system font.
Issues.Body:
### Related bugs and PRs:

- #4463 
- #8518 
- #8640 

### Background

The `ListBox` control `ItemHeight` property was decorated with a [DefaultValueAttribute] (This was changed by the #8518).
The `DefaultValueAttribute` for the `ListBox.ItemHeight` was the public const `DefaultItemHeight` property (a constant with value `13`). The problem with the constant value is that if application's default font is changed then the DefaultItemHeight will lose relevance.

As being explained in the DotNet Issue **[Define a pattern for default values that used to be constants proportional to the default system font](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/8599)** this leeds to extra code being generated for the `ListBox` control at the runtime: the generated code for ListBox had extra code for the ListBox .ItemHeight property.  And the generated property has value was not consistent with the old constant value.

### Suggestion
Use Control.DefaultFont.Height value as the default for the ItemHeight property.

1. remove the default value attribute from ItemHeight property;
2. make DefaultItemHeight` constant obsolete;
3. set the default ItemHeight value to the value of the static property `Control.DefaultFont.Height` (thus the ListBox.ItemHeight will be dependent on the height of the Application's Default Font);
4. change `ResetItemHeight` and add `ShouldSerializeItemHeight` methods that compare actual value against the dynamic runtime default.

### This is a breaking change

Per https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/coding-guidelines/breaking-change-rules.md#attributes. We make one attribute obsolete and we change the value of an attribute that is observable.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[API Proposal]: Define a pattern for default values that used to be constants proportional to the default system font." (#8751)

Issues.Title: SplitContainerDesigner is missing in .net6.0.
Issues.Body:
### Environment

 I have a project that uses the SplitContainer and its designer at runtime. It was working fine in .NET framework(4.8) but after upgrading to .net6.0 the control is not visible on designer site.

### .NET version

I have upgraded the project from .Net framework(4.8) to .Net6.0.

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

It was working fine in .Net Framework 4.8.

### Issue description

We have provided a feature to our customers in which the controls of the forms can be resized and relocated at runtime.
Then it is stored as a xml file and reloaded when reopened the same form.
After upgrading to .net6.0 the designer of the form is not visible in edit mode at runtime.

### Steps to reproduce

https://www.c-sharpcorner.com/UploadFile/asmabegam/easy-form-design-at-run-time-C-Sharp-winform/

### Diagnostics

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SplitContainerDesigner is missing in .net6.0." (#8749)

Issues.Title: Inline CodeDomComponentSerializationService.Trace method
Issues.Body:
Contributes to #8203

## Proposed changes

Method `CodeDomComponentSerializationService.Trace` is only called 5 times, including one time where it performs a useless check. I thought it would be simpler to just inline the method rather than adding a dedicated interpolated string handler.

Issues.Title: Multiline Checkbox text is deleted on Save
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2022 (64-bit) - Preview
Version 17.6.0 Preview 1.0


### .NET version

N/A

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

Unknown

### Issue description

When multiline CheckBox is created, using Designer, when form is saved the text is deleted.


### Steps to reproduce

Create a form, add a CheckBox, Use dropdown under CheckBox.Text to enter multiple lines of text. Hit <Control><Enter> to Save the  text and you will see it on the design surface. Now Save the Form. The text is deleted from Form.Designer.
[CheckBoxText Disapears.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/10877409/CheckBoxText.Disapears.zip)

### Diagnostics

```text
Silent. No errors.
```

Issues.Title: Convert Stack usage to Stack<T> where possible
Issues.Body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

Winforms uses legacy `Stack` collection at places where it could be easily swapped with the more modern `Stack<T>` without affecting public API

### Describe the solution you'd like and alternatives you've considered

Convert `Stack` usage to `Stack<T>` to remove needless casting.

### Will this feature affect UI controls?

Not that I'm aware of
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Convert Stack usage to Stack<T> where possible" (#8728)

Issues.Title: Replace Stack with Stack<T> across codebase
Issues.Body:
Fixes #8728


## Proposed changes

Convert `Stack` usage to `Stack<T>` in DesignerHost and UndoEngine

Issues.Title: Wrong text in ComboBox
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

6.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

ComboBox is added to the form and DropDownStyle is set to DropDownList.
Multiple items added to ComboBox and SelectedIndex set to 0.
In runtime you need to click on the button to open the items list and very quickly move the mouse pointer to any other value in the list then 0.
ComboBox displays wrong value in text box area.
Further, if you move the mouse pointer over the list items, then the value in text box area no longer changes.

Also this problem is reproduced in DrawMode = OwnerDrawFixed.

Video:
![ComboBoxIssue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/103027300/222373326-57a1e92d-c810-42bf-8f78-1496a9679cf6.gif)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create form, add ComboBox and set DropDownStyle to DropDownList, or use [sample app](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/10869021/TestComboBox6.zip) (then go to 3).
2. Add 6 items to ComboBox and set SelectedIndex to 0.
3. Run app.
4. Click on the button to open the items list.
5. Very quickly move the mouse pointer to any other value in the list then 0.
6. Observe wrong value in text box area.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Wrong text in ComboBox" (#8731)
